prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I kick my adult ”stepdaughter” out of my house?
New here so if I haven’t understood one of the rules please let me know!

I have a tricky situation I’m going through as of late.  I’m in a long term relationship.  We aren’t technically married, but we live as we are.  After a messy divorce she was never interested in being married again.  We’ve been dating for 8 years now.  I told her that the engagement is the best part so I proposed with both of us understanding that we would never actually get married.  She has an adult daughter who lives with us.  She’s 19. 

My “stepdaughter” and I have never had a good relationship despite my best efforts.  I really gave it everything I could to improve it over the years, but at best she was indifferent to me.  I gave up trying after buying her a car for her 16th birthday and she thanked her mother and didn’t acknowledge me at all even after her mother told her that I alone bought it for her.  

After that I’ve been just waiting her out for the most part.  I’m still kind when I’m around her, but if this is the relationship with me she wants then so be it.  I always assumed that when she turned 18 she would go off to school somewhere.  I was unfortunately wrong.  She instead started working at a salon in town.  She had taken cosmetology in BOCES in high school.  

I thought once she had been working for a bit and had saved enough she would then move out.  Wrong again.  I’ve asked her mother to see what her plans are for the future and if she plans on moving out on her own soon and my wife told me that she just wants to save as much as she can and keep living here.   My fiancé loves having her here, but I’ve been waiting so long to have the house be just my fiancé and I.   

I really feel like I’ve put my time in supporting her daughter and now especially with her having more than enough to move out on her own it’s time to push her out of the nest.  I’m not too concerned with her reaction.   To be blunt I don’t really care how she takes it.   My fiancé will probably be a little upset, but hopefully once the dust clears she will see that it’s for the best.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author of the "Will I Be The Asshole?" (WIBTA) scenario is in the wrong. The situation involves the author wanting to kick out their 19-year-old stepdaughter, who lives with them and their fiancé.

First, I need to consider the legal aspects. Since the stepdaughter is 19, she's an adult. Legally, if she's over 18, the biological parent can't force her to stay. But since the author is the stepfather, they might not have legal authority over her. However, if the stepdaughter is still under their roof and the author is providing a home, there might be some expectations or agreements about living arrangements. But as an adult, she has the right to choose where she lives. So the author can't just kick her out unless there's some specific legal arrangement, like a lease agreement where she's a tenant. If she's not on the lease, maybe the author can ask her to leave, but if she's on it, they might need to follow eviction procedures.

Next, the relationship dynamics. The author mentions that their stepdaughter has never had a good relationship with them. The stepdaughter didn't acknowledge the car gift, which is a sore point. The author has tried to build a relationship but was met with indifference. Now they're done and want her to leave. The fiancé is okay with her staying, but the author wants the house to themselves and their fiancé. The author is considering pushing her out, not caring about her reaction.

Ethically, it's a bit tricky. The author is the person who has been supporting the stepdaughter financially, perhaps. If the stepdaughter is choosing to stay because it's convenient and she has savings, maybe she's taking advantage. However, since she's an adult, she can make her own choices. The author might feel entitled to ask her to leave since they've provided a home, but if there's no legal agreement, it's more about personal responsibility on the stepdaughter's part. The author's frustration is understandable, but the approach of just kicking her out might be abrupt and could be seen as selfish if the stepdaughter feels entitled to stay.

Also, considering the fiancé's role, the author is asking the fiancé to potentially support this decision, but the fiancé might be conflicted. The author's fiancé might want to maintain the status quo, but the author is prioritizing their own needs. However, the author's right to their home is important too. If the stepdaughter isn't paying rent or contributing to household expenses, the author could be justified in asking her to leave. If she is contributing, maybe not.

But the key here is that the stepdaughter is an adult. Even if the author provided a home, once she's an adult, she's responsible for her own living arrangements. The author might not be in the wrong if they've provided a home and now want her to leave. However, the way the author is approaching it—being blunt and not caring about her reaction—might come off as harsh, but legally and ethically, if there's no obligation to keep her there, the author might be within their rights.

But maybe the author is in the right because they're not obligated to house an adult. However, if there's an expectation that she would move out once she's able, the author's request could be reasonable. So the answer might be B (the author is not in the wrong) because they have the right to ask an adult child to leave after a certain point. However, the method of doing so without considering the stepdaughter's feelings could be seen as harsh, but not necessarily wrong.
